doc.field: First German helpers on the way to Taiwan

After the heavy earthquake in Taiwan the first German helpers are on their way into the disaster area. Among the helpers are search dog teams and technical rescuers. Several countries including Germany, Japan, and the U.S.A. have offered financial aid. The earthquake was the strongest one in Taiwan in this century. It is assumed that at least 1700 people were killed and more than 4000 were injured.
Israeli Prime Minister visiting Berlin

Israel's Prime Minister Ehud Barak has arrived for a one-day visit in Berlin tonight. Right after his reception in the Chancellor's Office the first talk with Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder had been scheduled about the Middle-East peace process. Tomorrow morning Barak will meet German President Johannes Rau. Afterwards, he will visit the concentration camp memorial Sachsenhausen.
Federal Labour Minister Riester wants to back private pension plans

Federal Labour Minister Walter Riester wants to support private pension schemes. He has suggested that employees earning up to 60.000 DM annually receive up to 250 DM per year as a government benefit. In addition, Riester wants to promote early retirement so that those who retire at age 60 do not have to give up up to 18 percent of their pension. For the next rounds of collective bargaining Riester wants unions and employers to set up funds that would cover the loss of pension. The whole scheme would receive tax benefits.
Quarrel about reform of Green party leadership continues

Buendnis90/Gruene continue to argue about the reform of their leadership. Member of parliament Hans-Christian Stroebele said the party's left wing would resist Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer's plans to allow members of the party executive to hold government offices. Stroebele fears that this would give the executives too much power.
Fee collection letters by a fake EU authority

Letters by a nonexistent EU authority demanding the payment of a fee have now also surfaced in Baden-Wuerttemberg. Unknown impostors have sent letters with the letterhead of a European Commission for Environmental Protection demanding the payment of an eco-reserve fund contribution of 58.85 DM. Police warn against sending any money.
Central bank confirms positive economic trend

The German economy is growing again. The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank reports this month that since the beginning of this summer the economy has grown about five percent. Especially foreign companies have ordered more from German companies since July. Domestic demand has also risen.
Lehmann's chairmanship German bishop's conference confirmed

The archbishop of Main, Lehmann, has been reelected to chair the German bishop's conference. Over the coming days, the bishops at the conference must decide whether they will comply with the Pope's demands and withdraw from the Catholic discussion on the pregnancy conflict. Lehmann is assuming that the Church will decide on the withdrawal. He also said that, in the future, the proof of mandatory counseling form would probably be discontinued. However, he appealed to every bishop to make a decision regarding his own diocese.
Federal Prosecutor drops charge against so-called Caliphs of Koeln

State prosecutor Nehm has dropped the charges against the so-called Caliphs of Koeln. He accused the Turkish fundamentalists of leading a criminal organisation and of having instigated the murder of an apostate.
Trials for the murder of a drugdealer from Trier begin

Today, in the State Court, the murder trials against two Italians begin. Both men, aged 31 and 36, are accused of having shot a drugdealer last year in order to gain possession of his cocaine. It concerned 150 grams of cocaine worth 14.000 DM.
Trials against human smugglers begin in Dresden

Today, seven men and two women must justify themselves before the State Court for smuggling people. They stand accused of having smuggled more than 1000 people over the border between the Czech Republic and Germany between 1997 and 1998. A number of transports had to be aborted, since the people in the overloaded lorries nearly suffocated. They were then simply abandoned on the roadside.
Raisa Gorbachev's body brought to Moscow

Raisa Gorbachev's body has been flown from Muenster to Moscow in a Russian state airplane. In Moscow, Raisa is due to be buried in the Novodevichy cemetery. Her husband, Mikhail Gorbachev, has expressed his gratitude for the help and sympathy he has received.
Houses searched of the West German LB board members

Tax officials have searched the offices and houses of board members of the West German state bank. The public prosecutor's office in Duesseldorf suspects them of illegally funneling customer's money to Luxemburg and Switzerland.
Jan Ullrich hangs on to yellow jersey even after the 16th leg

The professional cyclist Jan Ullrich is still in possession of the leader's yellow jersey even after the 16th leg of the round of Spain from Valence to Teruel. The day's winner was the Belgian Frank Vandenbroucke, with Ullrich coming in 12 minutes after the winner.
